data.text: Do You Use a Kickstand or Click Stand when Touring by Bicycle?
Do you use a kickstand? Click stand? Lean your bike up against a wall or post? Or do you just lay your bike on the ground?
I use a click stand. Cant really fault it.
data.author: Andri Freyr Sigur√∞sson

data.text: Lay bike on ground or lean against wall (something sturdy)

data.text: Park it with the others üòÜ I mostly lean it against something solid, with a strap through the front wheel and frame. While wild camping finding a stick to prop it up is better than laying your bike on the ground.

data.text: I lean, but my front wheel tends to roll when loaded. In other posts I‚Äôve read about using elastic bands to engage your brakes, but no details on what they‚Äôre called or where to get them. When there‚Äôs nothing to lean on, we lean our bikes into each other‚Äôs

data.text: I've read that you can use sturdy hair elastic bands. They are cheap and can find them everywhere.

data.text: The rubber bands on broccoli are just the right size...
data.author: Bill Burke

data.text: Really depends on where I stop... If there is solid ground, I use the standard kickstand. If the ground is too soft, I lay the bike down. If there is something to lean it on, I will usually do that.
data.author: Josh Dunn

data.text: Depends on which bike I'm riding. :)
data.author: Pel Deal

data.text: I use a front and a rear kickstand together. It sure makes loading panniers on the front easier.
data.author: Mark Perry

data.text: Mostly lean is against something - post, poke, wall, rock or my partner‚Äôs bike. If not loaded I can use the pedal to balance on a curb. My last resort is to lay it on the ground .

data.text: Yes. Kickstand. Chainstay mount. I have a click stand and used to use it. Too much hassle. Yes walls trees posts other bikes Yes lay it down. Can‚Äôt fall if you lay it down
data.author: Tom Cavan

data.text: No shortage of trees in New England. Use a strap or such around the front brake, or a strap from the front wheel to the down tube, preventing wheel flop or roll.
data.author: Lee Hollenbeck

data.text: Leaners have holes in their handgrips. Clickstanders have an allen bolt problem that takes two weeks to tighten. Leaners have side burned seats. Clickstanders have spring and plate squeaks. Layers have holes in handgrips, side burned seats and pedal button scrapes.

data.text: Like the convenience of these

data.author: Justin Ashcroft

data.text: All my bikes have kickstands. Just put one on a new bike last week. Had to cut it to the correct length.
data.author: Dana Allen

data.text: I haven't found a kickstand which will support a rig like mine but when I settle down for the night I tether my bike close to my tent with my hard ground spike and spare guy rope - on uneven ground I also secure one of the brakes with a rubber lashing (strip of old inner tube) attached to the brake lever.
data.author: John Crinion

data.text: excellent idea üëç
data.author: Neil Steeper

data.text: No kickstand. I use a little ‚Äúwedge‚Äù thingy I‚Äôve had for 30+ years made by Blackburn. It wedges in the front brake lever firmly clamping on the front wheel. If the front wheel can‚Äôt spin, the bike can be safely leaned against any wall without fear of the bike falling over.

data.text: No chance would I lean my bike up the wall it might damage her üòÇüö≤ kick stand all the way

data.text: Some of these new kickstands are very stout, and they leave the crank free to move. Great for cleaning the drivetrain.
data.author: Pedaling Pete

data.text: I use a Click-Stand now. First tour I‚Äôve ever used one on. Before I leaned it against something. Finally bought a Click-Stand after scratching my paint to hell.

data.text: very similar to my Novara I have an ortlieb 3 r a c k on the back and tubus Tara on the front
data.author: RobertandTammy Fancher

data.text: I just lay it down. In my experience, kickstands and other gimmicks don't work very well on a fully loaded bike. The bike is going to wind up on the ground anyway, so I'd rather put it down carefully than have it fall over.
data.author: Steve Johnson

data.text: I had a Raleigh Portage with a dedicated boss for a flickstand. I found all kinds of weird devices for it on ebay, including a downtube cable stop and a flickstand with cable stops. I ended up ditching the whole idea and sold the bike before I could scratch it up.

data.author: David Meltzer

data.text: You sure got lots of options. I use a double stand. Sturdy, can work on the bike, adjunct gears, and brakes and clean it with ease. The only problem I have is that the bolt keeps coming loose. I use a lock washer, lock tite, check it often, but cannot solve this problem. Not serious, just irritating.
data.author: Bill Heimann

data.text: I have a conundrum. I do not like the idea of laying my bike down the ground or laying against something and I don't like a bolt on kickstand I like the idea of a click stand

data.text: Depends on the bike. My unicycle & low-racer recumbent, I lay on the ground. My gravel bike has a kickstand, and I use it. My velomobile has 3 wheels & a parking brake.

data.text: I use a couple of big reusable cable ties on the brake levers to hold the brakes on (or anything that will pull and hold the brake levers). Then just lean against anything. Biggest problem with fully loaded bike is the front wheel moves and bike jackknifes. Stop the wheels from turning, and bike is stable. Also will buy a few seconds if someone tries to walk away with your bike - it becomes an immovable object.
